Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: A Quantitative Approach to Detecting Meltdowns in Individuals with Autism Spectrum Disorder
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project will be the improvement of the quality of lives of both the individuals with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) and their caregivers. The prevalence of autism has increased by 15% in 2014. Now, 1 in 59 children born in the US has ASD. This translates to roughly 5.5 million individuals in the US who are less likely to go to college or find a job after high school. Our user-friendly, discreet device can help affected individuals gain independence and create a supportive learning or working environment for them. Pre-emptive meltdown detection and care devices are virtually non-existent in the current marketplace. As the first to enter the market at an affordable price point, we expect to lead and spawn derivative products. Beyond autism, our platform technology can be utilized to push data to a healthcare professional, catalyzing informed and personalized preventive care. Other conceivable application is monitoring compliance and measuring the effectiveness of rehabilitation exercises for muscle engagement of stroke patients. Our innovation also has the potential to reach and assist those affected by other types of anxiety disorders. It can help people become more informed about their own mental health, intervene, and lead healthier lives.

This I-Corps project involves wearable technology for predicting, detecting, tracking, and mitigating meltdowns for individuals with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD). We have developed a biometric sensing suite comprising two components: The hardware portion consists of a detachable, water-resistant core unit for biosignal filtering, processing, and transmission as well as machine washable sensors that can be embedded into apparel; The software portion consists of our proprietary machine learning models for determination of when a meltdown is to occur, alerting the parent or caregiver of a high risk of a meltdown, and an assessment of mitigation techniques afterwards. Our innovation will advance autism research, as the technology has the potential to open the doors to a better understanding of behavioral phenotypes. Being able to tell what a non-verbal child is feeling can pave the way for more efficient and productive lessons for social/education development as well as broader phenotypical research. The assessment feature of our product will lead to the improvement of mitigation techniques for meltdowns. gaia's competitive advantage is in its pre-emptive nature of care. Proof-of-concept was demonstrated, and a beta prototype will be complete by the end of Summer 2018.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

This I-Corps project involves wearable technology for predicting, detecting, tracking, and mitigating meltdowns for individuals with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD). The Entrepreneurial Lead (EL) Brent Chase founded the company, gaia wearables, and has developed a biometric sensing suite comprising two components: The hardware portion consists of a detachable, water-resistant core unit for biosignal filtering, processing, and transmission as well as machine washable sensors that can be embedded into apparel; the software portion consists of gaia’s proprietary machine learning models for determination of when a meltdown is to occur, alerting the parent or caregiver of a high risk of a meltdown, and an assessment of mitigation techniques afterwards.

The major goals of the project were: (1) Conduct customer discovery based on the Business Model Canvas; and (2) Based on the results of the customer discovery, make a decision on committing to the innovation’s transition beyond its current startup status. Both goals were accomplished. In Summer 2018, the team – EL, Industry Mentor (M) Neil Kleinberg, and Principal Investigator (PI) Gloria Kim – developed and revised the team's value proposition and conducted over 300 customer discovery interviews. Based on the data, the team made a Go decision and pursued NSF SBIR funding in December 2018. The project pitch was invited to submit a full proposal to the NSF SBIR/STTR Phase I program in the Sensors, and Wireless Technologies area.

In January 2019, the EL was named the 2019 Future Founders National Fellow. The Fellowship is a year-long cohort that accelerates the development of the top 18 to 30-year-old entrepreneurs in the nation. Fellows benefit from mentoring, entrepreneurship retreats, a peer community, and volunteer opportunities through Future Founders programs. The 2019 Fellows represented 10 states and businesses in industries including consumer products, food, services, and tech.

The Fellowship provided new insight for gaia’s leaders. With new goals – increase engagement on social media by 10%; complete the minimal viable product of the hardware; ready demo app by the end of Summer 2019 – set and accomplished, the company entered the 2019 HealthTECH Startup Competition and became one of the 10 finalists.

Broader Impact

Gaia Wearables has been engaged with the ASD community since its founding. Through the project, the company has formed partnerships with local ASD parent support groups in the Northeastern Region of the US and the advocacy group Autism Speaks. The EL was a speaker at South by Southwest (SXSW) 2019. The company has submitted a proposal to the SXSW 2020 PanelPicker. The company will be represented at SXSW 2020 by its COO.

Gaia's competitive advantage is in its pre-emptive nature of care. The innovation will advance autism research, as the technology has the potential to open the doors to a better understanding of behavioral phenotypes. Being able to tell what a non-verbal child is feeling can pave the way for more efficient and productive lessons for social/education development as well as broader phenotypical research. The assessment feature of the product will lead to the improvement of mitigation techniques for meltdowns.

Beyond autism, gaia's platform technology can be utilized to push biometric data to a healthcare professional, catalyzing informed and personalized preventive care. Other conceivable application of the technology is monitoring compliance and measuring the effectiveness of rehabilitation exercises for muscle engagement of stroke patients.
